snippet: “Inclusionary zoning” is producing too few units for low-income New Yorkers, and developers should be required to build more of them, the report says.
abstract: Report by the office of City Councilman Brad Lander says that inclusionary zoning, program created by New York City in effort to promote affordable housing, is producing too few units for low-income New Yorkers; Housing Preservation and Development Dept officials say economic downturn has affected participation from developers but that  interest in program has been picking up.
lead_paragraph: “Inclusionary zoning” is producing too few units for low-income New Yorkers, and developers should be required to build more of them, the report says.

headline.main: Report Finds a City Incentive Is Not Producing Enough Affordable Housing
headline.print_headline: Report Finds a City Incentive Is Not Producing Enough Affordable Housing

keywords.value: Assn for Neighborhood and Housing Development
keywords.name: organizations
